serinfo.issue: 2008 World, Europe, United States, Canada, and Mexico

descript.abstract:
World Time Zones is a polygon theme representing the time zones of the world. The time zones are best displayed with World Countries or World Administrative Units.
This dataset is a part of the 2008 ESRI Data and Maps Collection.
descript.purpose: World Time Zones provides time zones for countries and cities within them. Note that daylight-savings time is not shown.

For support, you may contact ESRI Support Center by telephone (voice) between 6:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Pacific time, Monday through Friday, by dialing 888-377-4575; facsimile (fax) available at 909-792-0960; electronic mail (e-mail) support@esri.com; or visit http://support.esri.com/; ESRI holidays excluded.
Outside the United States Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local ESRI International Distributor. This information can be found at http://gis.esri.com/intldist/contact/.
For other questions or comments, you may contact ESRI headquarters by e-mail, telephone, or fax or write to us.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.1.0.722

dataqual.logic: The shapefile is converted to SDC (Smart Data Compression) format using either ESRI SDC Data Development Kit Professional 2 (DDKP2) or tools in ArcGIS. The SDC data set is then loaded into ArcSDE to verify and validate the geometry.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal positional accuracy is unknown.

procstep.procdesc: This data set was created from several sources and finalized. Most features are based on a generalized version of the ArcWorld 1:3M coverage. The country and administrative unit boundaries were utilized for most of the zone boundaries. In a few instances, the ArcUSA 1:2M county level data for the United States and the ArcAtlas data for some zone boundaries in Russia were used. Most of the zones in ocean areas followed lines of longitude and latitude and were mathematically generated. The values of plus and minus hours from Greenwich are from a Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) map and the Rand McNally New International Atlas.

The following steps were performed by ESRI for Data & Maps 2002: Extracted the finalized data set. Updated areas in Canada including Nunavut. Densified arcs at 0.1 decimal degrees to maintain curvature of longitude lines when projecting. Generalized arcs at .02 decimal degrees. Created regions based on the Zone attribute. Output the data set as a shapefile. Created ArcGIS layer file (.lyr), projection file (.prj), and spatial indices. Converted the data set to SDC.

The following steps were performed by ESRI: Added SQKM attribute and calculated its values. Added SQ_MI attribute and calculated its values. Added COLORMAP attribute and calculated values between 1 and 8.
The following steps were performed by ESRI: Densified all features so the data set lines project more smoothly.
The following steps were performed by ESRI: Corrected the east, north, and south geographic extents. Converted the data set to SDC.

enttyp.enttypd: The polygon regions represent the thirty-eight time zones of the world and give a zone's difference in hours from Greenwich Mean Time.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The difference in hours between the zone and Greenwich Mean Time. Negative numbers represent zones west of 0 degrees Longitude and positive numbers represent zones east of 0 degrees Longitude.
The measure of area in square miles.
The measure of area in square kilometers.
The number allows the country to be shaded unique from its neighbors.
